Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Architecting Socio-Technical Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center for Architecting Socio-Technical Ecosystems will focus on accelerating understanding of socio-technical ecosystems by organizing research around certain core themes: Business Opportunities, Technical Design, Governance Regime, Collaborative Infrastructure, and Interactions and Simulations. Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) and the University of Michigan (UM) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with CMU as the lead institution.

Socio-technical ecosystems are emerging as unprecedented engines of innovation. The proposed center would examine important issues around the development and use of information technology solutions/software, right alongside with examining the structure, dynamics, and governance of the groups that create these solutions. The two universities are taking advantage of existing strengths in computer science and the social sciences surrounding technology. The problems addressed by the center are compelling and address a growing need as for-profit and non-profit entities weave their ways through a complicated collaboration and IP landscape to create new solutions, and to catalyze their adoption by users. The proposed center will enable rapid progress on theory development, empirical results, technology design, and tools for analysis and support.

The proposed center has the potential to improve the software industry. Innovation at the social technical interface has the potential to improve US industries. These new products and services could be disruptive technologies in the market place. Students and faculty members will gain valuable experience by interaction with industry partners. Both institutions have diversity plans in place and view a diverse student body and faculty as important to programmatic success.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Michigan contributed to the development of COASTE (Center on Architecting Socio-Technical Ecosystems), a research center to help the US software industry benefit from application of "platform-based ecologies" in the development of new applications and services. Platform-based ecologies, notably Apple's App Store, are powerful mechanisms for orchestrating and unleashing the creative energies of millions of software developers. The scientific benefits of COASTE include better understanding of factors that lead to successful platform-based ecologies (e.g., what incentives lead developers to contribute to an App Store-like system?).  From a societal perspective, COASTE will play an important role in maintaining and extending the competitiveness of US software producers.

Our funding from NSF allowed us to plan and participate in the organizational meeting for COASTE held at Carnegie Mellon University in July 2011.  At this meeting, scientists from Michigan and Carnegie Mellon joined with representatives from leading software firms (e.g., IBM, Microsoft, Google) to coordinate the COASTE agenda.

The result of the COASTE planning process was positive, with Carnegie Mellon going forward with the launch of the Center.  Unfortunately, projects proposed by Michigan scientists were not  aligned with the priorities of the initial Center partners. Therefore, plans to involve Michigan were put on hold pending identification of new Center partners or evolution of new projects of greater relevance to Center investors.


Last Modified: 06/04/2012
Modified by: Thomas Finholt
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The University of Michigan contributed to the development of COASTE (Center on Architecting Socio-Technical Ecosystems), a research center to help the US software industry benefit from application of "platform-based ecologies" in the development of new applications and services. Platform-based ecologies, notably Apple's App Store, are powerful mechanisms for orchestrating and unleashing the creative energies of millions of software developers. The scientific benefits of COASTE include better understanding of factors that lead to successful platform-based ecologies (e.g., what incentives lead developers to contribute to an App Store-like system?). From a societal perspective, COASTE will play an important role in maintaining and extending the competitiveness of US software producers. Our funding from NSF allowed us to plan and participate in the organizational meeting for COASTE held at Carnegie Mellon University in July 2011. At this meeting, scientists from Michigan and Carnegie Mellon joined with representatives from leading software firms (e.g., IBM, Microsoft, Google) to coordinate the COASTE agenda. The result of the COASTE planning process was positive, with Carnegie Mellon going forward with the launch of the Center. Unfortunately, projects proposed by Michigan scientists were not aligned with the priorities of the initial Center partners. Therefore, plans to involve Michigan were put on hold pending identification of new Center partners or evolution of new projects of greater relevance to Center investors.
